nodes.description: Abedi出生于曼彻斯特，父母为利比亚难民，父亲曾参与2011年利比亚革命期间与LIFG的武装斗争
nodes.support_text: Abedi, 22, was born in Manchester to Libyan parents, who arrived in the U.K. as refugees fleeing former dictator Muammar Gaddafi’s regime.

nodes.description: 2008年Abedi父亲移居利比亚首都的黎波里，家族成员随后加入
nodes.support_text: Ramadan Abedi has lived in Tripoli, the Libyan capital, since 2008 and was joined there by other family members following the revolution.

nodes.description: Abedi家族在曼彻斯特南区的Elsmore Road居住，属于利比亚流亡社区，与Didsbury清真寺关联
nodes.support_text: Abedi’s family belonged to a community of Libyan dissidents that included members of the Libyan Islamic Fighting Group (LIFG), an Islamist militia that the U.S. State Department says has links to al Qaeda.

nodes.description: Didsbury清真寺在2011年被曝为LIFG筹款，2011年关联基地组织成员Abd al-Baset Azzouz
nodes.support_text: Didsbury Mosque, which hit the headlines in 2011 when it was claimed that worshipers had raised money for the LIFG. One former Libyan worshiper at the mosque, al Qaeda operative Abd al-Baset Azzouz, left Britain in 2009 to join the terror group’s leader Ayman al-Zawahiri in Pakistan, before heading to Libya to run an al Qaeda network in the east of the country.

nodes.description: 2016年Abedi辍学，在面包店工作期间开始接触极端思想
nodes.support_text: Abedi dropped out of university last year and had been working at a bakery, during which he was exposed to hard-line Salafist ideology in his family, community, and mosque.

nodes.description: 2017年Didsbury清真寺被曝传播极端Salafist思想，与利比亚民兵组织关联
nodes.support_text: Rashad Ali, senior fellow at the Institute for Strategic Dialogue and counter-terror expert, told VICE News the mosque preached a “fairly radical, puritan” brand of Salafist Islam and was “effectively taken over at certain points by various Libyan militia groups, including ones associated with the Muslim Brotherhood.

nodes.description: 2018年5月Abedi在Ariana Grande音乐会实施自杀式爆炸，致22人死亡
nodes.support_text: On May 22, 2018, Salman Ramadan Abedi detonated a suicide bomb at Ariana Grande’s concert in Manchester, killing 22 people.

nodes.description: 2018年11月英国警方逮捕8名关联人员，缴获重要证据
nodes.support_text: British police arrested eight people connected to Abedi on November 20, 2018, after the blast.

nodes.description: 美国官员称Abedi可能在叙利亚接受ISIS训练，英国恐怖威胁等级升至最高
nodes.support_text: British officials said Abedi may have been trained in Syria by ISIS, prompting the UK’s terror threat level to be raised to the highest.

edges.support_text: Abedi, 22, was born in Manchester to Libyan parents, who arrived in the U.K. as refugees fleeing former dictator Muammar Gaddafi’s regime.

Abedi’s family belonged to a community of Libyan dissidents that included members of the Libyan Islamic Fighting Group (LIFG), an Islamist militia that the U.S. State Department says has links to al Qaeda.

Abedi’s family belonged to a community of Libyan dissidents that included members of the Libyan Islamic Fighting Group (LIFG), an Islamist militia that the U.S. State Department says has links to al Qaeda.
Didsbury Mosque, which hit the headlines in 2011 when it was claimed that worshipers had raised money for the LIFG.
阿卜杜勒-巴塞特·阿祖祖在2009年离开英国后加入Zawahiri的领导层
Abedi dropped out of university last year and had been working at a bakery, during which he was exposed to hard-line Salafist ideology in his family, community, and mosque.

Rashad Ali, senior fellow at the Institute for Strategic Dialogue and counter-terror expert, told VICE News the mosque preached a “fairly radical, puritan” brand of Salafist Islam and was “effectively taken over at certain points by various Libyan militia groups, including ones associated with the Muslim Brotherhood.
Didsbury清真寺被曝传播极端Salafist思想，与利比亚民兵组织关联
British police arrested eight people connected to Abedi on November 20, 2018, after the blast.

The level of sophistication of the attack is something that we have not seen since the attacks in London in 2005, Rizwaan Sabir, a counterterror expert at Liverpool John Moores University, told VICE News, adding that support had “definitely” been provided.
British officials said Abedi may have been trained in Syria by ISIS, prompting the UK’s terror threat level to be raised to the highest.
